standard_metadata.standard_description: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Compare decimals and fractions in different forms

hints.content: Let's compare $\pink{2.09}$ and $\blueD{1\text{ one and } 19 \text{ tenths}}$ with visuals.   *(Each big square represents one whole.)*  $\pink{2.09}:$|   - | - | - $\blueD{1\text{ one and } 19 \text{ tenths}}:$ |

images.alt: A big square is completely shaded pink.
A big square is completely shaded pink.
A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom row, the left 9 squares are shaded pink.
A big square is completely shaded blue.
A big square divided into 10 equal sized rectangles that are set in 10 rows of 1 rectangle each. All 10 rows with rectangles are shaded blue.
A big square divided into 10 equal sized rectangles that are set in 10 rows of 1 rectangle each. 9 bottom rows with rectangles are shaded blue.

hints.content: Now, let's rewrite $\blueD{1\text{ one and } 19 \text{ tenths}}$ as a decimal:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{1\text{ one and } 19 \text{ tenths}} = \blueD{2\text{ ones and } 9 \text{ tenths}} \\\\ &\blueD{2\text{ ones and } 9 \text{ tenths}}= \blueD{2.9} \end{align}$
$\pink{2.09}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{2.9}$, so $\pink{2.09}$ is **less** than $\blue{2.9}$.
$\pink{2.09}< \blue{1 \text{ one and }19 \text{ tenths}}$
Let's rewrite $\blue{\dfrac6{10}}$ as a decimal number:  $\blue{\dfrac6{10}} = \blue{6 \text{ tenths}}= \blue{0.6}$
Now we can compare $\pink{0.54}$ and $\blue{0.6}$ with visuals.   *(Each big square represents one whole.)*  $\pink{0.54}:$|  - | - | - $\blue{0.6}:$ |

images.alt: A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom 5 rows, all 10 squares are shaded pink. In the sixth row from the bottom, the left 4 squares are shaded pink.
A big square divided into 10 equal sized rectangles that are set in 10 rows of 1 rectangle each. 6 bottom rows with rectangles are shaded blue.

hints.content: $\pink{0.54}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.6}$, so $\pink{0.54}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.6}$.
$\pink{0.54}< \blue{\dfrac6{10}}$
Let's rewrite $\blue{2 \text{ tenths}}$ as a decimal number:  $\blue{2\text{ tenths}}= \blue{0.2}$
Now we can compare $\pink{0.08}$ and $\blue{0.2}$ with visuals.   *(Each big square represents one whole.)*  $\pink{0.08}:$|  - | - | - $\blue{0.2}:$ |

images.alt: A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom row, the left 8 squares are shaded pink.
A big square divided into 10 equal sized rectangles that are set in 10 rows of 1 rectangle each. 2 bottom rows with rectangles are shaded blue.

hints.content: $\pink{0.08}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.2}$, so $\pink{0.08}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.2}$.
$\pink{0.08}< \blue{2\text{ tenths}}$

Now we can compare $\blue{1.14}$ and $\pink{1.14}$ with visuals.   *(Each big square represents one whole.)*  $\blue{1.14}:$|   - | - | - $\pink{1.14}:$ |

hints.content: Let's rewrite $\blue{\dfrac{217}{100}}$ as a decimal:  $\blue{\dfrac{217}{100}} = \blue{2 \text{ ones and } 17 \text{ hundredths}}= \blue{2.17}$
$\pink{2.7}$ covers **more** area than $\blue{2.17}$, so $\pink{2.7}$ is **greater** than $\blue{2.17}$.
Let's rewrite $\blue{5\text{ hundredths}}$ as a decimal number:  $\blue{5 \text{ hundredths}}= \blue{0.05}$
Now we can compare $\pink{0.5}$ and $\blue{0.05}$ with visuals.   *(Each big square represents one whole.)*  $\pink{0.5}:$| - | - | - $\blue{0.05}:$ |

images.alt: A big square divided into 10 equal sized rectangles that are set in 10 rows of 1 rectangle each. 5 bottom rows with rectangles are shaded pink.
A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom row, the left 5 squares are shaded blue.

hints.content: $\pink{0.5}$ covers **more** area than $\blue{0.05}$, so $\pink{0.5}$ is **greater** than $\blue{0.05}$.
$\pink{0.5}> \blue{5 \text{ hundredths}}$
